TIME — MIDNIGHT.</br>SCENE — GUINEA.

When Afric's Genius mourn'd an injur'd land,</br>And wrapt in clouds, her foe's destruction plann'd;</br>Tremendous, oft she shews her mangled form,</br>Derides the suff'rers, and enjoys the storm.</br>She sees the wild, the dread tornado driven</br>By all th' avenging ministers of Heav'n;</br>Bids the plague rage, disease in rivers flow,</br>And on her spoilers pours the cup of woe.

Beneath her ken the British bark was moor'd;</br>The traders vainly thought their prey secur'd:</br>What time the watch proclaim'd the midnight sound,</br>Their sickly mates in horrid slumbers bound;</br>High o'er the poop two sable Lovers glide,</br>And toil for freedom on the swelling tide.</br>The beach now gain'd, they joyful, hand in hand,</br>With ardent souls salute their native strand,</br>In mutual raptures on each other gaze,</br>Till Bura thus began with words of praise.

BURA.</br>Hail, heav'nly orb!  blest be thy gen'rous beam,</br>Whose living light plays o'er the peaceful stream;</br>And thou, O spirit of the liquid plain!</br>At whose command the monsters of the main</br>Obedient wait — blest be thy strength that bore</br>Thy humble vot'ries to their injur'd shore.</br>Now, Zelma, rise, and ere the morning's dawn,</br>O'er uplands pass we to the verdant lawn:</br>Far from the haunts of ruffian beach-men stray,</br>Or where the Whites with blood have mark'd their way—</br>The Gods survey us, and 'tis meet we share</br>In pain and peril, if we claim their care.

ZELMA.</br>Much Bura saw, yet Heav'n far more could see</br>Of what I dar'd for liberty and thee.</br>Support me, love!  support my feeble frame,</br>Nor let a woman's weakness meet thy blame.</br>Think how against the tyrant's wiles I strove,</br>Us'd every art t' evade his lawless love—</br>Now all is hush'd, thy wearied limbs now rest,</br>Receive my soul into thy constant breast.</br>Yon verdant bank, near that palmetto's shade,</br>Invites our stay—

BURA.</br>—Come then, thou lovely maid;</br>And now the wand'ring moon glides thro' the trees,</br>And sultry plains inhale the cooling breeze:</br>We'll all our suff'rings, all our woes relate,</br>The captive's thraldom, and our country's fate.

Once happy land!  where all were free and blest,</br>And love and friendship sooth'd each care to rest;</br>Where age rejoic'd to see his offspring take</br>The quaint meander thro' the limpid lake;</br>Where nightly sports regal'd the sprightly throng,</br>And plenty smil'd at cheerful labour's song.</br>To ruthless strangers now a fenceless prey,</br>And native ruffians yet more fierce than they.

ZELMA.</br>Once happy land!  blest were the blooming bow'rs,</br>Where youthful virgins tranquil pass'd their hours;</br>Where Bura sought, well pleas'd, the cooling grove,</br>And brought each eve the tokens of his love,</br>The uncouth stranger in that grove is seen,</br>Frightful in arms, and grim his threat'ning mien.

BURA.</br>Deceitful men!  when first our shores they view'd,</br>For needful food with plaintive tales they su'd;</br>Their artful guides, from Ante's faithless strand,</br>With proffer'd friendship hail'd our happy land:</br>But in the dread and silent hour of night</br>Consuming fires the peaceful hamlets 'fright;</br>Then, like a lion eager for his prey,</br>Among the throng I boldly forc'd my way.</br>My strength full well their haughty leader knew,</br>And from mine arm the pallid dastards flew.</br>Why need I say what swarms from ambush rose!</br>How dragg'd in chains by these unfeeling foes</br>O'er trackless sands, till on the Volta's tide</br>You bless'd my sight, my life, my better guide!

ZELMA.</br>Fast by the rock from whence our riv'let flows,</br>My pensive sire that eve had sought repose,</br>Where pendent shrubs their balmy sweets entwine</br>To form a shade, and broad-leav'd plantains join.</br>My custom late his aged steps to tend,</br>When dreadful shrieks the vales and woodlands rend.</br>Struck dumb with fear, I saw their strange attire,</br>When high in air they wav'd the dreadful fire.</br>Thus down the steep the foaming floods appear,</br>When sudden storms destroy the plenteous year.</br>With tott'ring steps, by dire distraction led,</br>Thro' tangling woods and dreary dells we fled;</br>But nought avail'd — beset by fresh alarms,</br>They tore me, fainting, from a father's arms.</br>Nor need I now my sorrows here disclose,</br>Since, blest with thee, I half forget my woes.

BURA.</br>Speak ever thus, and ever thus appear,</br>No trader's taunts nor shipman's threats I fear;</br>Such rugged souls no sweet sensations prove,</br>Who spoils his country, ne'er can taste of love.</br>Oh, think what trouble rent his throbbing breast,</br>When lovely Zelma pin'd, and sat distrest!

ZELMA.</br>Unheard-of crimes and tortures met my eyes,</br>That call'd for vengeance from th' impartial skies;</br>My gloomy thoughts oft sunk me in despair—</br>Blown by the winds thro' seas, we knew not where;</br>And, worse than all, to be their passion's slave!</br>T' avoid his suit, I brav'd the dashing wave.</br>That morn, thou know'st, when Sestro bold and strong,</br>(Who to the moon could chaunt the mystic song)</br>Sprang o'er the prow — breasting the briny waves—</br>In frantic mood the curst commander raves.</br>Now the rude engines sent forth sulph'rous flame,</br>The mortal thunder miss'd its deadly aim,</br>And happy Sestro gain'd his native shore—

BURA.</br>Yet what ensu'd must pity's self deplore:</br>I saw the White, the trembling guard secur'd,</br>On him his chief's unpitying vengeance pour'd;</br>The furies rag'd within the tyrant's breast,</br>While cringing minions act the damn'd behest;</br>His arms extended to the shrouds were ty'd,</br>While clotted gore the pale beholders dy'd.</br>That pow'r who hears the dying victim's pray'rs,</br>Beneath the knotted whip clos'd all his cares—</br>What the reward?  Oh what the mighty meed!</br>In foreign lands ye make each other bleed:</br>Or are ye exiles, doom'd to drag your lives</br>On hellish schemes — from country and from wives?</br>No lenient herbs your ulcer'd bodies heal,</br>The wrathful vengeance you severely feel,</br>And draw-in pest'lence with your latest breath,</br>With putrid meals devour the feeds of death.—

ZELMA.</br>Pining and pale, I view'd the sickly race;</br>Alas, they're men!  tho' crimes their souls debase,</br>In fev'rous fits they talk of wives and friends;</br>The hand of death alone their torture ends.</br>Tho' great the meed, why quit your native land?</br>The Gods of wrath your forfeit lives demand;</br>For rav'nous sharks, those messengers of fate,</br>Around your ship with dread commission wait.—</br>Know, ere the sun shall burst the cave of night,</br>Or golden clouds shall tinge the mountain's height,</br>A warlike chief hath faithful friends prepar'd,</br>With engines meet to bind the drowsy guard,</br>Or plunge him headlong in the gloomy deep,</br>And free the captives while the tyrants sleep.</br>My love-fraught bosom, ever prone to fear,</br>Still kept the precious secret from thine ear.

BURA.</br>Too timid Maid! — when could I better die,</br>Than thus for friendship, love, and liberty?</br>In all his aims still may that chief succeed:</br>Methinks I see the cruel tyrants bleed!</br>Altho' unus'd to war, inspir'd, I feel</br>My strength revive — Oh for the pointed steel,</br>To hurl swift vengeance on the pallid foe!

ZELMA.</br>—Hark, Bura!  heard'st thou not the scream of woe</br>Where sinks the moon beneath yon dusky hill,</br>Behold the bark — what fears my bosom fill!</br>What moving fires along the decks now gleam,</br>And gain reflected horror from the stream!</br>This way they float — mark how the flames ascend—</br>Just Heav'n!  the weak and innocent defend.

BURA.</br>The Gods are rous'd — hark!  now their thunders roll,</br>And now shall shrink each trembling tyrant's soul.</br>O Friends!  O Countrymen!  be greatly bold,</br>For justice strike, nor thus be tamely sold:</br>You fight for Heav'n, the cause that gave you breath,</br>Brave ev'ry fear, and challenge manly death.</br>Would I were there — to clasp me thus forbear—
ZELMA.</br>Why shook the earth? — behold the darken'd air!

BURA.</br>Thus rapt in clouds the lofty mountain shakes,</br>When from the skies the vivid light'ning breaks;</br>Tremendous, thus, rebounds the thunder's roar,</br>When rueful swains their fields and flocks deplore.</br>The Whites no more at suff'ring wretches smile,</br>Nor more majestic floats their lofty pile.</br>See o'er the deep its shatter'd fragments roll,</br>Our injur'd Gods their dark designs controul.

ZELMA.</br>Now all their fears, and tears, and suff'rings cease;</br>The Gods are good, and take their souls to peace:</br>Guilty and guiltless now are seen no more.</br>Alas!  my love, fly, fly this fatal shore.

BURA.</br>The barren beach, ye sons of rapine, prize;</br>Yes, fertile fields and groves shall meet our eyes.</br>Say, what are all your treasures brought from far,</br>But vice, intemp'rance and a rage for war?</br>Then, Zelma, haste!  to distant wilds we bend;</br>Content and Peace shall on our steps attend.</br>
